comment:
Not sure if my taste has changed but I’m getting a sweet vanilla on this one. 
Wife got it for me for a special occasion... Thursday!
Tastes like beer vodka. Not good
Really sweet and creamy. Good with coffee.
Smooth with honey in the end
Geaux-too blended Irish whisky; the best blend to add to coffee.
floral, vanilla sweetness, biscuit, citrus, no burn, very smooth to drink,
Mellow, sweet, smooth, Blueberry after taste
Apple crumble, fresh apples, spice, oaty malt biscuits, cream/butter, caramel, brandy, rum, fresh wood, vanilla, coconut, pepper. Smooth mouth feel, spicy at the end, young wood finish.
Simple oak aroma, Warming sensation once it hits the lips bit sweet and touch of fruit flavours

On the nose, lights fruits, predominantly green apple and citrus.  Accompanied by a pine tartness. 

On the palette, there is a sweetness, but flavor is extremely light. Slightly oaky. Personally, I find very little flavor here. 

The finish fades quickly, and the limited flavors that were initially present quickly disappear. 

Overall, it is a light and friendly whiskey. I imagine a more finely-tuned connoisseur can discover the flavors here. For me, there’s not enough to justify devoting any more time or money towards this product.

I know it's an icon, but I am just not a fan.  The flavors are hidden in the dryness.(Like a painfully dry Sauvignon Blanc but not in a good way) The nose seems interesting enough, but it doesn't translate into flavor.  I do not favor very sweet drams, but this dry short finish is more than I can take.  It is available everywhere and it doesn't break the bank.  Unfortunately, it does nothing for me...except make me exceptionally thirsty.
Shortbread, biscuit, vanilla cream, baking spice

I was tired of trying only bourbon brands with names I recognized, so I walked in the store to pick something different up. Overwhelemed with options, I found the next-most familiar name available and picked this up. You can't go wrong with it. Give it as a gift, or drink it with some friends. This one is meant to be shared.
slight ethanol, tart, grainy, fruity, kinda soapy

Wonderful mix of single pot and grain whiskeys. One of the smoothiest drams I have ever tasted. Can be enjoyed neat, on the rocks and in coctails. Jameson, ginger ale and a wedge of lime is a classic. Great whiskey all in all. 
When I prepare my Irish Coffee cocktail I prefer to have more robust whiskey than Jameson. Maybe Jameson Black Barrel.

Surprisingly good and smooth, i really enjoyed this dram. Totally unexpected since it is a cheap accesible whiskey. 

On the nose you get Chocolate,Orange, Pine, Plum and a little Vanilla.

On the palate, is very smooth and sweet and refreshing with cocoa and orange notes. Finish is very short
Light cereal nose. Pleasant on the palate with sweet cereal notes. Short finish. Nothing fancy but a smooth, pleasant dram.
Leaves a warm and cozy mouthfeel.
Always a great choice. Smooth and delicious. Love to mix with ginger ale
Somehow weirdly similar to my Bulleit taste... nice in the nose; but astringent tannins on the back end.

Nose is fresh and bright, super fruity with aroma of peaches & pears for days, followed by some honey and apples.

Palate starts off sweet, then transitions into buttery apples with a hint of citrus.

Finish is quick and dry with not much else going on. 

A fine Irish whisk(e)y for the money... I like to start with this to prime the system before getting into something more substantial.
Sweet vanilla nose. Smooth mouth feel. Quick finish with nothing left to the imagination.
Smooth. Tried with ginger ale and lime. Better with ginger ale chaser.

Flavor:  woody
Taste: round, woody, smooth
Finish: medium

Alcoholic nose with some
honey. Honey and vanilla on the palate
with a sharp, bitter finish.
Some wood, black pepper, a bit of a metallic note, and a lasting sweetness underneath. Really good budget Irish. Completely inoffensive and perfect for many drinks.

El caballito de batalla de los whiskys irlandeses triple destilados. Ideal para comenzar el viaje de la suavidad y tratamiento de la semillas con vapores y no humos. Ya en nariz empieza la experiencia. Tanto para alguna medida solo o usarlo para tragos suaves considerandolo en eso.
Very light.  Few phenols and esters. Residual sweetness is pleasant. Fresh crushed black pepper note on the back end. An enjoyable drink.

As this was my introduction to whiskey, it will always remain as one of my favorites. Sweet taste and aroma, and quite affordable. It will always be in my shelf for my guests, my cocktails and myself.
Smooth with good flavor but lacks depth.
Tart taste with amazingly smooth finish
Standard sweet Irish. Honeyed butter and biscuits. Add a dash of a strongly peated budget Islay for a great contrasted but friendly dram!

Nose: Floral with a touch of copper pot aroma. Subtly fruity, mainly banana and apple coming through. Some rich sweetness of vanilla. Slightly oaky as well.

Palate: Pretty quiet actually despite having such an active nose. Very slight amounts of fruit blending with a decent amount of malty flavor. Some grassy notes and slight spice.

Finish: Brief. Malt strongest here and the oak from the nose comes back to say goodbye. A pleasant and crisp finish.

Overall Thoughts: I certainly won’t act like this is the first time I’ve ever had Jameson. It’s the most popular Irish whiskey on the planet. And I think it holds that title for a good reason, it’s a damn good whiskey. No, it isn’t the greatest thing you’ll ever have in your life, but it’s complex enough to start a flavor/aroma debate, and it’s not offensive or overpowering in the way that some lower-priced whiskeys are. I always have a bottle of Jameson at home. Never a bad choice, in my opinion.
Damn fine daily drinker and makes a mean cocktail.

Nose: overall a gentle sweetness, some raisins & chocolate
Taste: warm and sweet, in the beginning some spices. Some chocolate and coffee.
Finish : general warmth, some pepper
Featured in a mixed drink at St. Patrick’s Day 2017 in Delray Beach. Peeps, Razzi, Mezz, Toni-Ann, Kim and Meg spring break trip. Frequently used for shots in college.

Nose: Green apple, vague sweetness. As I sipped I started to pick up on a spice smell I can’t quite place.
Palate: Green apple keeps going with a butterscotch coating. Little oak. Smooth, alcohol is almost unnoticeable.
Finish: Butterscotch fades quickly and leaves a trail of oak behind it.
Light. Hint of vanilla. Sweetness between bourbon and scotch.
My mid week choice mixed with dry ginger ale, a squeeze of fresh lemon and plenty of crushed ice. A reliable quencher!
